content.webTitle: Cycling: Victoria Pendleton targets four golds to boost Olympic case

fields.headline: Pendleton targets four golds to boost Olympic case
fields.bodyText: The injustice of having only one opportunity to win a gold medal at the Beijing Olympics still rankles with Victoria Pendleton, so she intends to highlight the case for equality at London 2012 by challenging for four at the world track cycling championships, which begin tomorrow. Pendleton could do no more in Beijing than she did, which was to win one gold in the sprint – as opposed to her male counterpart, Chris Hoy, who claimed three – but here in the Warsaw suburb of Pruszkow she intends to win the four she believes she is capable of. "Last year the 500 [metres time trial] was squashed between the sprint heats so it wasn't possible practically [to do it]," said Pendleton, whose campaign for four golds begins with the 500m, followed by the team sprint, sprint and keirin. "This time around I'm really doing it because I can." The women of the all-conquering British track team could outshine the men, with Wendy Houvenaghel, the Beijing silver medallist, favourite for the women's pursuit in the absence of the Olympic champion, Rebecca Romero. The men's team sprint will see Matt Crampton attempt to fill the absent Hoy's shoes, by joining two-thirds of the triumphant trio from Beijing, Jamie Staff and Jason Kenny. "The French are going well, but we're pretty confident," said Staff. "Matt is a very good rider – people forget how good he is."
